reviewText:
Early Access Review

Possess all the enemies. What's not to like? That mechanic alone made this an instant no brainer. This is a must get for people who like emergent gameplay.

If you're familiar with the first A Wizard's Lizard, this is improved in every way. If you're new, you don't have to go back and play the previous game, because this stands so well on its own.

The two developers are very open about their development process and very responsive to feedback. If you like to get involved in the process of making a game, this is a great one to get early.

Right now (4/5/16) the only downside is a lack of content. This is because the guys have been working hard on getting core game design elements RIGHT before pumping out broken and unfun game elements. Lately they have been pushing out content and the game is rapidly filling out. I expect the content problem to be very temporary.

This game is seriously worth your time. It was certainly worth mine.

Early Access Review

Full disclosure: I'm an avid Lostcast-listener (the devs' podcast) and am as such already emotionally invested. But, seriously - this is a REALLY good game!

I played the first instalment quite a bit, but, with hindsight, I can see it wasn't really for me. I'm not a very twin-stick-shootery guy, and while I definitely had a good time with the game, much of my value came from being involved in the development discussion.

With Soul Thief it is different. I absolutely still enjoy following the development process (and if you're at all interested in game dev, so will you!) through the podcast and forums, but I also really enjoy the GAME.

It might not be obvious at first but Soul Thief is radically different from AWL1. Gone is the endless ammo, leaving you to rely on your tail whip which requires you to get up close and personal. Sometimes you get wands which give you a ranged attack, but since the ammo is very limited the sense of danger never leaves.

And, of course, the possession mechanic. It works SO well! The death mechanic of the first game, while a cool idea, never really took off (sorry Matt & Geoff!). But being able to play as the monsters in this game is not a mere gimmick - since health is so scarce it is a way of survival, and you always feel rather naked when you have to use your Raga vessel. Also the various monsters have radically different attacks and play styles, which makes for a really fun experience and opens up tactical choices.

The graphics are also a major improvement over the first game - it keeps the same charm, but with more detail and more character.

The game is still a bit thin on content - this is early access, after all - but I'm really impressed with how it already feels like a complete experience in spite of that. The core gameplay is simply really solid!

Wrapping up; Soul Thief sports a really enjoyable gameplay that is only going to improve as development progresses and content grows. Heartily recommended!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Short version:
Did you play A Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past growing up? Do you like random dungeons, loot, and or wizards and or LIZARDS?!! Well then this is the game for you!

Long version:
I really love games. There is no other way to say it. Board games, video games, whatever it may be, there is just something so fun and alluring about being dropped into another world, figuring it out, and accomplishing whatever challenges it sets out before you.

I was fortunate enough to be allowed to experience this game for the last couple of weeks, and I have had a great time for all the right reasons.

Firstly, the game is hard, but its difficulty is not a gimmick. Its challenges are understandable and fair. It is very obvious the developers spent a lot of time thoughtfully crafting this experience to make sure you can figure out what's going on around you, to allow you to formulate your own thoughts on how to accomplish your goals, your own way, without bombarding you with tutorials or text that stop you from enjoying the game.

The possession mechanic keeps you on the edge of your seat. Jumping from monster to monster just barely escaping death is exciting- just as choosing the right monster for the right situation makes you feel smart. Coupled with getting your favorite wand can make you feel unstoppable, but running out of charges makes you appreciate the game's difficulty.

As you progress you will find that because the developers did such a good job of ensuring you understand the game's threats and mechanics, you will become quite masterful- my favorite part of a game is when they challenge you to do something outside of your comfort zone, but still allow you to do it 'your' own way. This is exactly what the meta progression of this game encourages. Your skill alone is the key to another interesting challenge just around the corner.

The game is still in development obviously, but it has a level of polish that is really refreshing. The sound effects, and little extra bounces and animations are just really very pleasing, impressive, and appreciated. The music is catchy and fun; sooner or later you will hum along while playing it. The aesthetic is brilliant- a mix of cute and gruesome, without being too much of either. The lighting effects create a really fun and unique ambiance, that makes you want to stay just a bit longer...

Okay, I've said a lot of good things about AWL: Soul Thief, so are you ready for the bad?!

Well honestly I've got nothing for you. Of course it's not perfect, but it's exactly what it should be, an interesting, unique, rewarding, challengingly fun experience that leaves you wanting more- and thank goodness because it's only just now coming to early access, which the developers have stated they want to add a bunch more to this game before they are done. I don't know about anyone else, but I can't wait to see what other fun exciting stuff they come up with.

Whether you buy it or not, I hope you have fun playing whatever you're playing these days, because I am always amazed that we live in a time where you can just sit down at your computer and dive into a world other people spent so many hours bringing to life for you to enjoy.

-Vox

Early Access Review

Disclosure: I was included in the Alpha Test of this game - this review is of the game in its current state (0.9.0).

Soul Thief is an interesting take on top-down rogue-lites - possessing of monsters introduces a fun mechanic allowing the player to play as a wide array of monsters with different and unique play-styles.

Fans of the original game will find some great updates;

The game as a whole is far more refined, with a clear sense of design within the various levels, and overall far more endearing character design.

The gameplay itself has shifted from a twin-stick shooter design to a combination of melee and ranged attacks, and there is a fantastic array of spells you can use to tear enemies apart. The combat is tighter, and more focused, which is a recurring theme withing the game, even in Early Access, everything feels more solid.

It's a shame I'm not very good at it - hopefully there's some melee centric additions heading my way.

Finally, a note on Early Access - the developers are incredibly engaged in their community, and I feel it's safe to say that they will continue to work hard to make this game something special.

10/10 DID buy again.

Early Access Review

I highly recommend this game and the podcast (Lostcast) that the develoeprs produce, especially for aspiring gamedevs. This is their second rogue-lite and even in the early stages of development their design and gamedev experience is showing. The game is still in Early Access so you expect things to be in flux and to have some hiccups. That said, I was very surprised with how polished the game already is for an Early Access game (probably since they could leverage a lot of the first game's code).

For me though, the value of this game is in following the developers progress and design decisions throughout the project. They are extremely transparent on their podcast and it's a ton of fun watching the game improve and hearing the ups and downs of their process. To me it's a bit like kickstarting a project except you can play right now and you get way more out of it than a few micro blog posts from the devs. Supporting the developers will also help make the game better at release because the devs are constantly responding to and considering fan feedback on the forum.
